channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Big Ben Bongs Will Soon Ring Out Again Across London
item.description: Next to the Houses of Parliament, the tower that houses the enormous bell has been undergoing renovation since 2017.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Elizabeth Tower, called the Clock Tower until it was renamed in 2012, has been refurbished at a cost of about $97 million.

item.title: Investigators of War Crimes in Ukraine Face Formidable Challenges
item.description: International agencies are joining Ukrainian prosecutors in what may be the biggest effort ever to hold war criminals to account. But the difficulties and dangers they face are exceptional, too.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A witness to the death of Oleksiy Ketler standing over his coffin.

item.title: In Northern Ireland, Brexit and Legislation Revive Old Challenges
item.description: Brexit and so-called legacy legislation are reviving sensitive issues of Catholic and Protestant identity that civic leaders have sought to dampen.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Peace Bridge, which opened in 2011, connects the Catholic and Protestant sides of Derry, Northern Ireland.

item.title: Palestinians Give U.S. Bullet That Killed Shireen Abu Akleh
item.description: Officials believe that the bullet, which killed Shireen Abu Akleh, could hold essential clues as to who is responsible for her death.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial at the site where Shireen Abu Akleh was killed in the West Bank.

item.title: Ukraine War Volunteers Die in Battles Far From Home
item.description: Many of the fighters for Ukraine’s western territorial defense units were assigned benign tasks away from the fighting when they first joined. Then they were called to the front to fight.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of Yurii Brukhal, an electrician by trade, who was killed in some of the war’s fiercest fighting.

item.title: Lysychansk, Ukraine’s Last Outpost in Luhansk, Falls to Russia
item.description: Lysychansk managed to hold out for a week after its twin city, Sievierodonetsk, was captured. But on Sunday a pro-Russian flag flew there, as well.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Kamila Hrabchuk and Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lysychansk, Ukraine, last month. Russia subjected the city to prolonged bombardment.

item.title: In Pakistan, a Leader in Trans Rights, Reality Is Slower to Change Than Law
item.description: Four years after the country became one of the few to protect transgender people’s rights in statute, violence against them has surged and discrimination remains common.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: A transgender woman known as Madam Kashish begging for money in May in Karachi, Pakistan. It is difficult for many in the transgender community in Pakistan to find jobs.

item.title: From the Early Morning Sky, Shards of Hot Metal
item.description: Ukrainians reacted in fury to a Russian missile strike near Odesa, the latest in a string of attacks on civilian targets.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Detention in Moscow Is Latest in Hostage Diplomacy
item.description: The United States believes the charges against the basketball star are spurious and tied to American support of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, center, arriving for a court hearing on Friday outside Moscow.

item.title: Japan Swelters Through a Punishing Heat Wave
item.description: Temperatures in Tokyo surpassed 95 degrees for the eighth straight day on Saturday, a streak seen only once before since 1875.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Issei Kato/Reuters
item.media:description: Seeking respite from the heat this past week under a cooling mist in Tokyo.

item.title: ‘Long Live the Theater’: Mariupol’s Drama Company to Perform Again
item.description: Thirteen members of the Mariupol Drama Theater have reconvened in western Ukraine where they are rehearsing a new play about a Ukrainian dissident who died in a Russian prison camp in the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Actors from Mariupol’s Academic Regional Drama Theater rehearsing for a new play in Uzhhorod, in western Ukraine, this month.

item.title: Why Is There So Much Turmoil in Eastern Congo?
item.description: More than 120 militia groups are wreaking terror in the Democratic Republic of Congo, which now accuses neighboring Rwanda of backing one particularly violent group.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Congolese army tank heads towards the front line in eastern Congo in May.

item.title: Labeled a ‘Challenge’ by NATO, China Signals Its Own Hard-Line Worldview
item.description: The alliance’s forceful declaration in its mission statement reinforced Beijing’s belief that hostile powers are bent on hobbling the country’s ascent.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden joining NATO leaders for a group photo on Wednesday at the NATO summit in Madrid.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A Russian assault on eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Donetsk on Thursday.

item.title: In Ukraine, U.S. Veterans Step In Where the Military Will Not
item.description: Special Operations veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia, despite warnings from the Pentagon.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Perry Blackburn Jr., who recently returned from Ukraine, organized supplies last month as he prepared for his next trip to the country.

item.title: Australia’s Prime Minister Promises More Aid During Ukraine Visit
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky described the visit as the first by an Australian prime minister to his country during their history of diplomatic relations.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nariman El-Mofty/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, right, with the Australian prime minister, Anthony Albanese, during a press conference, in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Seizes Lysychansk
item.description: Plus a heat wave engulfs Japan and transgender activists in Pakistan debate protections.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman touched the portrait of late Ukrainian soldier Anatoly Mykolayovych Potaychuk, 40, inside the church before going to the cemetery for burial during a funeral ceremony in Babyntsi, in Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: At Least Six Die in Glacier Collapse in Italy’s Dolomites
item.description: The glacier has been shrinking for years, and recent high temperatures may have contributed to the collapse, a rescue service official said.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Alpine Rescue Services, via Reuters

item.title: Three Dead in Denmark After Shooting in Copenhagen Mall
item.description: The police said that one person was in custody but that it was too early to suggest a motive for the shooting, which happened at the Field’s shopping center on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel and Jasmina Nielsen
item.media:credit: Ritzau Scanpix/Via Reuters
item.media:description: Terrified shoppers fled for safety after a gunman opened fire at a mall in Copenhagen on Sunday, leaving three people dead and at least three others critically wounded.

item.title: Why the City of Lysychansk Is a Big Prize in Putin’s War Strategy
item.description: Controlling the cities of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk means Russia could position its forces to mount offensives on cities to the southwest.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rose above the Ukrainian cities of Lysychansk and Sievierodonetsk after heavy Russian bombardment last month.

item.title: Behind the Scenes of the Supreme Court
item.description: Getting a sense of the mood after a momentous term.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Climate activists gather at the Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., following the ruling of the court on West Virginia v. EPA on Thursday.

item.title: Abortion Laws in Europe, Canada, Mexico and Other Countries
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court’s ruling on abortion quickly led to bans in at least seven states, a shift toward criminalization that runs counter to recent easings in countries that had longstanding bans.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Activists clashing outside the U.S. Supreme Court on June 27, days after it eliminated the constitutional right to abortion. The ruling contrasted with recent decisions by high courts in Mexico and Colombia, which have moved to decriminalize abortion.

item.title: Women who were raped by Russian soldiers yearn for justice.
item.description: Rapes were among the many atrocities Russian troops inflicted on Ukrainian civilians during weeks of occupation in the Kyiv suburbs and elsewhere. But the challenges of prosecuting the assaults are daunting.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktoriya and a neighbor were raped by Russian soldiers, who also killed two men, including her neighbor’s husband.

item.title: Four Killed After Explosions in a Russian City Near the Ukraine Border
item.description: The Russians said its air-defense systems shot down three missiles, but one fell to the ground in central Belgorod.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Vasily Maximov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Russian city of Belgorod in 2019.

item.title: In Estonia, Ethnic Russians Start Questioning Putin’s War
item.description: Narva, in northeastern Estonia, is the E.U.’s most ethnically Russian city, with a population supportive of President Vladimir Putin. But the conflict in Ukraine has set off a “mental war” between old and young.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Marta Giaccone for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bridge over the Narva River that separates Ivangorod, Russia, from Narva, Estonia. Some ethnic Russians in Narva are starting to doubt the Kremlin’s official narrative about the war in Ukraine.

item.title: The fight for the last city in Luhansk under Ukrainian control reaches a pivotal point.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Anatolii Stepanov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: After weeks of heavy fighting in Lysychansk and its surroundings, Ukrainian forces appeared to be pulling back from the city as Russian troops threatened to surround it.

item.title: Lesia Tsurenko Plays Tennis to Earn Money to Help Ukraine
item.description: She used to compete because she loved tennis, but now Tsurenko wants to win as much prize money as possible to help people in her war-torn country.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman

item.title: Russia Steps Up Pace of Missile Attacks on Civilian Targets
item.description: The Russians’ growing use of imprecise Soviet-era missiles to terrorize civilians reflects the daunting outlook of its offensive despite incremental gains, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian missile strike Friday on a nine-story apartment building in Serhiivka, in the Odesa region of Ukraine, killed at least 21 people.

item.title: This regional leader is a symbol of Ukrainian defiance.
item.description: Vitaliy Kim is the head of the regional military administration in the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vitaliy Kim has worked to puncture the legend of Russia’s might. “It was important to convey that the enemy was not as scary as it seemed, and to tell the world that we are here, that we exist,” he said.

item.title: His Union Went on Strike. His Interviews Went Viral.
item.description: At a time of rampant inflation and wage stagnation, Mick Lynch, the force behind Britain’s largest railway strikes in three decades, has found success that has surprised even his colleagues.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon
item.category: National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT)
item.media:credit: Saskia Solomon/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mick Lynch, the general secretary of the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers, has used a series of combative television interviews to build public support for the union.

item.title: Ukrainian Students Are Hopeful and Defiant as They Graduate Amid War
item.description: For these students, this coming-of-age moment amid the war is especially poignant.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alina Pyda, 16 (on the left in the blue dress), and fellow pupils celebrating their school graduation in Uzhhorod, Ukraine.

item.title: Miners Discover a Frozen Baby Mammoth in Canada
item.description: Experts believe that the woolly mammoth, unearthed in the Klondike gold fields of the Yukon of Canada, had been preserved in the frozen ground for more than 30,000 years.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Treadstone Equipment
item.media:description: A worker for a mining company in the Yukon made an important discovery while digging in the permafrost: the remarkably well-preserved body of a baby woolly mammoth.

item.title: Ukraine Accuses Russia of Dropping White Phosphorous on Snake Island
item.description: Some observers speculated that the strike was a move to destroy equipment that Russia had abandoned on the island and to complicate any future Ukrainian presence there.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Chief of Ukraine's General Staff Valeriy Zaluzhny via Reuters
item.media:description: A still from a surveillance video showing explosives dropped on a location given as Snake Island in this image released on Friday by the chief of Ukraine’s General Staff via Telegram.

item.title: A Guide to Fourth of July Weekend
item.description: Recommendations for a summer holiday — movies, podcasts, “Stranger Things” and cobbler.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Russia Repeatedly Strikes Ukraine’s Civilians. There’s Always an Excuse.
item.description: The Kremlin’s explanations have sometimes satisfied the Russian people, but they fall apart under closer scrutiny abroad.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Examining the wreckage of a complex damaged by Russian bombardment in May in the center of the city of Kharkiv in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine Dreams of Rebuilding the World’s Largest Airplane. Can Richard Branson Help?
item.description: A Virgin Group spokesperson said the effort would turn to finding ways the international community could support the project.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: What was formerly the world’s largest airplane, the Mriya, was destroyed earlier in the war during heavy combat in the Hostomel airport, outside of Kyiv.

item.title: Japan’s Secret to Taming the Coronavirus: Peer Pressure
item.description: The country has never mandated masks or vaccinations, but it’s evaded the worst of Covid, thanks to a fear of public shaming and the “self restraint police.”
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Commuters at Shibuya Station in Tokyo in late June. Social conformity has been a key ingredient in Japan’s relative success against Covid.

item.title: Iran Earthquake Kills at Least 5, State Media Says
item.description: Iran’s state news agency said the quake, which did extensive damage to a village, was followed by two more.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:credit: Abdolhossein Rezvani/Associated Press
item.media:description: Clearing away debris on Saturday in the Iranian village of Sayeh Khosh, in Hormozgan Province.

item.title: At Comedy Shows in Lviv, Crowds Look for Humor Amid a Deadly War
item.description: At the Cultural Defense shows in Lviv, comedians and audiences look for humor amid a deadly conflict. Don’t mind the air raid alarms.
item.dc:creator: David Segal
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons pay about $13 apiece to watch the comics at a Cultural Defense show being performed at the Cult Comedy Hall, a club in downtown Lviv.

item.title: Biden Administration Offers an Offshore Drilling Plan. Likely Backers: Very Few.
item.description: The five-year plan for America’s coastal waters, required by law, risks angering both the fossil fuel industry and environmentalists.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Chris Carlson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Offshore drilling platforms near Huntington Beach, Calif.

item.title: Brittney Griner, Women’s Basketball Star, Goes on Trial in Russia
item.description: The American basketball star Brittney Griner has endured months in a Russian prison and the threat of years more, a wartime bargaining chip between Moscow and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brittney Griner arriving at court on Friday.

item.title: Did the ‘Freedom Convoy’ Change the Meaning of Canada’s Flag?
item.description: On Canada Day, some citizens were wary of raising the national flag, now also associated with weeks of protests against pandemic mandates.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: Some Canadians fear that the flag has become a symbol of protest rather than a symbol of the nation.

item.title: California Requires Plastics Makers to Foot the Bill for Recycling
item.description: The landmark legislation also restricts single-use plastics. Because California’s economy is so big, experts say, the law could have far-reaching effects.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin
item.media:credit: Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press
item.media:description: The California law is the fourth of its kind in the U.S., but experts say it’s the most significant.

item.title: With Climate Agenda Stalled at Home, Biden Still Hopes to Lead Abroad
item.description: The United States has demonstrated international leadership on climate change in the past, but recent setbacks are presenting new challenges for President Biden.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden addressed NATO nations at a summit in Madrid, Spain, on Thursday, hours before the U.S. Supreme Court ruled on a climate case.

item.title: Venice Will Require Tourists to Register and Pay Entry Fee
item.description: City officials are introducing a new fee to visit Venice and its islands, a move, they hope, will limit tourists.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Andrea Merola/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Beginning in January 2023, visitors to Venice, Italy, must make a reservation through a new digital system and many will have to pay a daily fee — from 3 to 10 euros.

item.title: UNESCO recognizes borscht as a Ukrainian dish in urgent need of safeguarding.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha Habro, 76, preparing borscht in Borshchiv, Ukraine, in 2020.

item.title: More Mexicans Are Migrating to the U.S. After a Decade-Long Drop
item.description: The death of at least 53 migrants in Texas, more than half of whom were from Mexico, is testing U.S. efforts to enlist Mexico in deterring migration.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Cristopher Rogel Blanquet for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yolanda Olivares, left, holding photos of her sons, Jair and Yovani Valencia Olivares, duing a march on Thursday in southern Mexico. The two brothers are missing and may have been among the migrants found in an abandoned trailer in Texas.

item.title: Will There Be Enough Monkeypox Vaccine?
item.description: A factory making Jynneos, the safest vaccine, has been closed since August, threatening global supplies as the virus spreads.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Gavino Garay/Reuters
item.media:description: A patient received the Jynneos vaccine in a clinic in Washington on Tuesday. Some experts are concerned that the demand for monkeypox vaccine will soon exceed the global supply.

item.title: Denmark’s Leader Apologizes for Botched Pandemic Mink Cull
item.description: The comments by Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen came after a report called the government’s decision in 2020 to kill some 17 million mink over coronavirus fears illegal.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Isabella Kwai and Jasmina Nielsen
item.media:credit: Morten Stricker/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A site near Holstebro, Denmark, where the government was disposing of dead mink in November 2020.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s case in Russia appears to be the latest example of ‘hostage diplomacy.’
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brittney Griner has become the latest example of hostage diplomacy, a practice that has seen a number of Americans swept up by hostile governments in the last few years.

item.title: Tunisia’s President, Kais Saied, Proposes New Constitution
item.description: The proposal, which will be put to a national referendum on July 25, would enshrine the significant steps he has taken over the past year to dismantle the North African nation’s young democracy.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Fethi Belaid/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Kais Saied of Tunisia suspended Parliament and fired his prime minister almost a year ago amid political paralysis and economic convulsions.

item.title: Benin Bronzes Returned to Nigeria from Germany
item.description: Two of the renowned artifacts were given back to Nigeria on Friday, and Germany intends to give the African country ownership of some 1,100 more.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: New Zealand Designates Proud Boys a Terrorist Group
item.description: The far-right Proud Boys are not known to operate in the country, but the designation makes it illegal for New Zealanders to support them.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Mark Mitchell/NZME, via Associated Press
item.media:description: New Zealand’s minister of police, Chris Hipkins, discussed the Proud Boys and the Base on Thursday in Wellington. “These are white supremacist terrorist groups,” he said.

item.title: Tropical Storm Bonnie Lashes Nicaragua and Costa Rica
item.description: Bonnie lashed Nicaragua and Costa Rica late Friday after becoming the second named storm of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Oswaldo Rivas/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: At a temporary shelter on Friday in Bluefields, Nicaragua, before Tropical Storm Bonnie made landfall.

item.title: The Kremlin rejects the suggestion that Griner’s case is politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: A Look Inside the Lockup Where Brittney Griner Has Been Held
item.description: At least one other well-known foreigner has spent time there: Naama Issachar, the Israeli-American arrested in April 2019 when the Russian police said they had found marijuana in her luggage.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Naama Issachar at a court hearing in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: The Court vs. the Climate
item.description: The Supreme Court seems unconcerned with climate change.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Thompsons, Tex.

item.title: Landslide in India Buries Dozens, Killing at Least 25
item.description: Days of heavy rain had loosened the soil. India and neighboring Bangladesh have had record rainfall and severe flooding in the past two months.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: National Disaster Response Force/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The scene in the Noney District of Manipur, India, on Friday, after a large landslide struck near a railway construction site.
